children.text: This is Lever Weekly, a recap of all of
‚Äôs work from the past week. If you only read one email from us all week, this should be it.
Following links to all of our articles, you‚Äôll find our weekly column connecting the dots on our coverage to deliver important takeaways. This week‚Äôs is our essay published in

that sums up our reporting on the governmental decisions that have touched off a possible bank crisis. If you‚Äôve been overwhelmed by all of this week‚Äôs complex news about the financial system, read this one column to get up to speed.
(Scroll to the bottom to read the column.)
Stuff The Lever Reported This Week:
Fed Insisted SVB Posed No Serious Risk To Financial System
Less than two years later, Fed Chair Jerome Powell cited systemic risk as justification to protect Silicon Valley Bank‚Äôs depositors.
Following lobbying efforts, the Federal Reserve exempted Silicon Valley Bank‚Äôs venture capital investments from a key risk management rule.
SVB‚Äôs Lobby Groups Fought Proposal To Bolster Deposit Insurance
Months before Silicon Valley Bank collapsed, its D.C. advocacy groups said the FDIC initiative ‚Äúwould unduly burden banks.‚Äù
Campaign Cash Goes In, Late Fees Come Out
Republican lawmakers funded by the credit card industry are fighting to protect the excessive fees companies charge consumers.
LEVER TIME: The Bank Panic of 2023
We explore the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and its impact on the U.S. financial system.
LEVER TIME PREMIUM: The Secrets Of Successful Whistleblowing
International whistleblower law expert Stephen Kohn shares tips and tricks from his new handbook.
LEVER LIVE: The Bank Panic Of 2023 With Ro Khanna, Saule Omarova, and Matt Stoller
Paid subscribers joined David Sirota and Julia Rock to speak with a progressive California congressman, a Biden nominee blocked for supporting bank regulation, and a financial policy expert.
WATCH NOW: The Lever‚Äôs Leading The Coverage Of The SVB Collapse
first uncovered federal documents outlining SVB's successful efforts to push back on banking regulations.
MOVIES VS. CAPITALISM: Office Space (w/ Adam McKay)
On this week‚Äôs MVC, Rivka and Frank are joined by Academy Award-winning filmmaker Adam McKay to discuss the workplace comedy Office Space.
WATCH NOW: David Sirota on Democracy Now!
Sirota appeared on Tuesday‚Äôs episode, ‚ÄúHow Silicon Valley Bank & Signature Bank Lobbied to Weaken Regulations That Could Have Prevented Collapse.‚Äù

children.text: Thank You To Our Newest Lever Leaders:
Lever Leaders provide us with our highest level of support and score additional perks in return.  Each week, we highlight folks who‚Äôve taken that step, and the reasons they say they‚Äôve done so.
is my eyes and ears. I want to see and hear as accurately as possible, especially facts and connections that are not brought into awareness by other news organizations.‚Äù
: ‚ÄúI believe that realizing the value of truth and honest reporting will be the only way we can save ourselves from mis- and dis-information in this entertainment media.‚Äù
Too Small To Regulate, Now Too Big To Fail
Silicon Valley Bank was supposedly the type of institution that would never need a government bailout ‚Äì right until its backers spent three days on social media
one, and then promptly receiving it, after the bank‚Äôs spectacular collapse last week.
Eight years ago, when the bank‚Äôs CEO, Greg Becker, personally
Congress to exempt SVB from post-2008 financial reform rules, he
its ‚Äúlow risk profile‚Äù and role supporting ‚Äújob-creating companies in the innovation economy‚Äù. Those companies include
typically opposed to the kind of government intervention they benefited from on Sunday, when regulators
to guarantee SVB customers immediate access to their

Fifteen years after the global financial crisis, the logic of ‚Äútoo big to fail‚Äù still prevails. The financial hardship of student debtors and underwater homeowners is a private problem ‚Äì but losses sustained by titans of tech and finance are a matter of urgent public interest. Moral hazard for thee, but not for me.

What‚Äôs more, SVB‚Äôs meteoric rise and fall serves as a reminder that many of the guardrails erected after the last crisis have since been dismantled ‚Äì at the behest of banks like SVB, and with the help of lawmakers from both parties beholden to entrenched finance and tech lobbies.

Before becoming the second-largest bank to fail in US history, SVB had transformed itself into a formidable influence machine ‚Äì both in northern California, where it became the go-to lender for startups, and on Capitol Hill, where it spent
in a five-year period lobbying for the deregulatory policies that ultimately created the conditions for its downfall.
‚ÄúThere are many ways to describe us,‚Äù SVB
on its website. ‚Äú‚ÄòBank‚Äô is just one.‚Äù
Indeed, SVB‚Äôs management appears to have neglected the basics of actual banking ‚Äì the bank had no chief risk
for most of last year, and failed to
on interest rates, which ultimately played a key role in the bank‚Äôs downfall. In the meantime, the bank‚Äôs deposits ballooned from less than $50bn in 2019 to nearly $200bn in 2021.

children.calloutText: Follow us on Apple News and Google News to make sure you see our stories first, and to help make sure others see our breaking news as well.

children.text: From the moment that Congress passed banking reforms through the 2010 Dodd-Frank law, SVB lobbied to defang the same rules that would probably have
regulators to spot trouble sooner. On many occasions, lawmakers and regulators from both parties bowed to the bank‚Äôs demands.
One of SVB‚Äôs first targets was a key Dodd-Frank reform aimed at preventing federally insured banks from using deposits for risky investments. In 2012, SVB
the Obama administration to exempt venture capital from the so-called Volcker Rule, which prevented banks from investing in or sponsoring private equity or hedge funds.
‚Äã‚Äã‚ÄúVenture investments are not the type of high-risk, ‚Äòcasino-like‚Äô activities Congress designed the Volcker Rule to eliminate,‚Äù the bank

to regulators. ‚ÄúVenture capital investments fund the high-growth startup companies that will drive innovation, create jobs, promote our economic growth, and help the United States compete in the global marketplace.‚Äù
After the Obama administration finalized the Volcker Rule in 2014 without a venture capital carveout, SVB sought its own exemption that would allow it to maintain
in venture capital funds, in addition to providing traditional banking services for roughly half of all venture-backed companies.
One such firm was Ribbit Capital, a
in the collapsed cryptocurrency exchange FTX, which lauded SVB‚Äôs tech-friendly ethos in a 2015 New York Times

. ‚ÄúYou can go to a big bank, but you have to teach them how you are doing your investment,‚Äù Ribbit‚Äôs founder told the Times. At SBV, ‚Äúthese guys breathe, eat and drink this Kool-Aid every day.‚Äù
In the transition between the Obama and Trump administrations, SVB got what it wanted: a string of deregulation, based on the idea that the bank posed no threat to the financial system.

testimony to Congress arguing that SVB, ‚Äúlike our mid-size peers, does not present systemic risks‚Äù ‚Äì and therefore should not be subject to the more stringent regulations, stress tests and capital requirements required at the time for banks with $50bn or more in assets.
Two years later, SVB was one of just a handful of banks to
a five-year exemption from the Volcker Rule, allowing it to maintain its investments in high-risk venture capital funds.
The deregulatory drumbeat grew louder in Congress, and in 2018 lawmakers passed
increasing to $250bn the threshold at which banks receive enhanced supervision ‚Äì again, based on the argument that smaller banks would never prove ‚Äútoo big to fail‚Äù.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell,

the deregulatory push. Under Powell, a former private equity executive, the Fed in 2019 implemented a so-called ‚Äútailoring rule‚Äù, further exempting mid-size banks from liquidity requirements and stress tests.
Even then, the banks‚Äô lobbying groups continued to push a blanket exemption to the Volcker Rule for venture capital funds, which Powell

Then, in 2021, SVB won the Federal Reserve‚Äôs signoff on its $900m acquisition of Boston Private Bank and Trust, on the grounds that the post-merger bank would not ‚Äúpose significant risk to the financial system in the event of financial distress‚Äù.
‚ÄúSVB Group‚Äôs management has the experience and resources to ensure that the combined organization would operate in a safe and sound manner,‚Äù Federal Reserve officials
Since the financial crisis, SVB has reported spending
on federal lobbying efforts, while the bank‚Äôs political action committee and executives have made nearly $650,000 in campaign contributions, the bulk to Democrats.
Among the highlights of this influence campaign was a 2016 fundraiser for the Democratic senator Mark Warner of Virginia,
by Greg Becker in his Menlo Park home. A few months later, Warner and three other Democratic senators
to regulators arguing for weaker capital rules on regional banks.
Warner went on to become one of 50 congressional Democrats who joined with Republicans to pass the 2018 Dodd-Frank rollback. When asked this week about his vote, Warner
: ‚ÄúI think it put in place an appropriate level of regulation on mid-sized banks ‚Ä¶ these mid-sized banks needed some regulatory relief.‚Äù
In the wake of SVB‚Äôs collapse, Republicans have not renounced their votes for deregulation ‚Äì nor have most of the Democrats who joined them, even as Biden is
Warner took to ABC‚Äôs This Week on Sunday to
his vote; Senator Jeanne Shaheen, the Democrat from New Hampshire,

NBC on Tuesday that ‚Äúall the regulation in the world isn‚Äôt going to fix bad management practices‚Äù. Senator Jon Tester, the Democrat from Montana and a co-sponsor of the 2018 deregulatory law, even held
in Silicon Valley the day after the SVB bailout was announced.
Unless they reverse course, the Silicon Valley Bank bailout could prove politically
for Democrats, who just oversaw the rescue of coastal elites in a moment of ongoing economic pain for everyone else.

children.productDescription: Score a copy of our Citizens‚Äô Guide to Following the Money and Holding the Powerful Accountable, free with a paid subscription. The e-book gives you all the tools and tricks our reporting team uses to scrutinize power.

children.text: The good news is that there are straightforward steps that Democrats can take to start fixing things.
Democrats can also revisit the areas where Dodd-Frank fell short, including stronger
risky behavior by banks by reforming bankers‚Äô pay. And they should demand that Powell
himself from the Federal Reserve investigation of recent bank failures and take a hard look at whether
merits outright dismissal under the Federal Reserve Act, which allows the president to fire a central bank chair ‚Äúfor cause‚Äù.

And yet even now ‚Äì amid the wreckage of deregulation ‚Äì these and other measures to better regulate the banks may still be nonstarters among both the Republicans and corporate Democrats who voted for the regulatory rollbacks and have so far shown
The words of the Illinois Democratic senator Dick Durbin still ring true, 14 years after the financial crisis.
‚ÄúThe banks ‚Äì hard to believe in a time when we‚Äôre facing a banking crisis that many of the banks created ‚Äì are still the most powerful lobby on Capitol Hill,‚Äù he
back in 2009. ‚ÄúAnd they frankly own the place.‚Äù
If that remains true today, the possibility of change looks grim.
